index.description:
This component applies an OpenStudio measure to an OpenStudio file. The component will eventually be integrated to Export to OpenStudio component.
Read more about OpenStudio measures here: http://nrel.github.io/OpenStudio-user-documentation/reference/measure_writing_guide/
You can download several measures from here: https://bcl.nrel.gov/nrel/types/measure
Many thanks to NREL team for their support during the process. See (https://github.com/mostaphaRoudsari/Honeybee/issues/214) and (https://github.com/mostaphaRoudsari/Honeybee/issues/290)for just two examples!

index.name: Balance Temperature Calculator
index.summary: Use this component to calculate a rough building (or zone) balance temperatrue from a Honeybee energy simulation
index.description:
Use this component to calculate a rough building (or zone) balance temperatrue from a Honeybee energy simulation. The balance point is the outdoor temperature at which your building is usually neither heating or cooling itself. If the outdoor temperture drops below the balance temperature, your building will usually be heating itself and, if the outdoor temperture is above the balance temperature, the building will usually be cooling itself.
The balance temperture concept is useful for setting things such as automated blinds and airflow shcedules since having these things controlled by hourly cooling or heating can often introduce odd behavior resulting from idiosyncrasies in the building's schedule.
This component works by taking the average combined heating/cooling values for each day and the average outdoor air temperature for each day. The days with the smallest combined heating + cooling will have their daily mean outdoor air tempertures averaged to produce the balance temperture.

index.name: Color Surfaces by EP Result
index.summary: Use this component to color zone surfaces based on EnergyPlus data out of the "Honeybee_Read EP Surface Result" component
index.description:
Use this component to color zone surfaces based on EnergyPlus data out of the "Honeybee_Read EP Surface Result" component.
By default, zone surfaces will be colored based on total energy per unit surface area in the case of energy input data or colored based on average value of each surface in the case of temperature or data that is already normalized.
If total annual simulation data has been connected, the analysisPeriod_ input can be used to select out a specific period fo the year for coloration.
In order to color surfaces by individual hours/months, connecting interger values to the "stepOfSimulation_" will allow you to scroll though each step of the input data.

index.name: Color Zones by EP Result
index.summary: Use this component to color zones based on EnergyPlus data out of the "Honeybee_Read EP Result" component or zone comfort analyses out of the comfort calculator components
index.description:
Use this component to color zones based on EnergyPlus data out of the "Honeybee_Read EP Result" component or zone comfort analyses out of the comfort calculator components.
By default, zones will be colored based on total energy per unit floor area of the zone in the case of energy input data or colored based on total average value of each zone in the case of temperature, humidity or comfort input data.
If total annual simulation data has been connected, the analysisPeriod_ input can be used to select out a specific period fo the year for coloration.
In order to color zones by individual hours/months, connecting interger values to the "stepOfSimulation_" will allow you to scroll though each step of the input data.

index.name: Construct Energy Balance
index.summary: This component accepst the outputs of the "Read EP Result" and the "Read EP Surface Result" components and outputs a data tree with all of the building-wide energy balance terms
index.description: This component accepst the outputs of the "Read EP Result" and the "Read EP Surface Result" components and outputs a data tree with all of the building-wide energy balance terms. This can then be plugged into the "Ladybug_3D Chart" or "Ladybug_Monthly Bar Chart" to give a visualization of the energy balance of the whole model.

index.name: Energy Plus Window Shade Generator
index.summary: Use this component to generate shades for Honeybee zone windows
index.description:
Use this component to generate shades for Honeybee zone windows. The component has two main uses:
The first is that it can be used to assign shade objects to HBZones prior to simulation. These shades can be dynamically controlled via a schedule. Note that shades created this way will automatically be assigned to the zone and the windowBreps and shadeBreps outputs are just for visualization.
The second way to use the component is to create test shade areas for shade benefit evaluation after an energy simulation has already been run. In this case, the component helps keep the data tree paths of heating, cooling and beam gain synced with that of the zones and windows. For this, you would take imported EnergyPlus results and hook them up to the "zoneData" inputs and use the output "zoneDataTree" in the shade benefit evaluation.

index.name: Energy Shade Benefit Evaluator
index.summary: This is a component for visualizing the desirability of shade in terms of energy simulation results by using solar vectors, the outdoor temperature, and the simulation hating load, cooling load, and beam gain
index.description:
This is a component for visualizing the desirability of shade in terms of energy simulation results by using solar vectors, the outdoor temperature, and the simulation hating load, cooling load, and beam gain.
Solar vectors for hours when the building is heating contribute positively to shade desirability while solar vectors for hours when the building is cooling contribute negatively. This conrtibution is weighted by how much the building is cooling or heating in realtion to the solar beam gain through the window in question.
The component outputs a colored mesh of the shade illustrating the net effect of shading each mesh face. A higher saturation of blue indicates that shading the cell is very desirable. A higher saturation of red indicates that shading the cell is harmful (blocking more winter sun than summer sun). Desaturated cells indicate that shading the cell will have relatively little effect on outdoor comfort or building performance.
The units for shade desirability are net kWh saved per unit area of shade if the test cell is blue. If the test cell is red, the units are net heating kWh harmed per unit area of shade.
The method used by this component is based off of the Shaderade method developed by Christoph Reinhart, Jon Sargent, Jeffrey Niemasz. This component uses Shaderade's method for evaluating shade and window geometry in terms of solar vectors.
A special thanks goes to them and their research. A paper detailing the Shaderade method is available at:
http://web.mit.edu/tito_/www/Publications/BS2011_Shaderade.pdf

index.name: Thermal Autonomy Analysis
index.summary: Use this component to calculate 'Occupied Thermal Comfort Percent' (occTCP) and 'Thermal Autonomy' (TA) from the resultd of a Microclimate Map Analysis
index.description:
Use this component to calculate 'Occupied Thermal Comfort Percent' (occTCP) and 'Thermal Autonomy' (TA) from the resultd of a Microclimate Map Analysis.
'Occupied Thermal Comfort Percent' (occTCP) is defined here as the the percent of occupied time where a point of space meets or exceeds a given set of thermal comfort acceptability criteria.
Precedents for Thermal Comfort Percent (TCP) as a metric to spatially evaluate the desirability of a given space can be found in the PhD thesis of Tarek Rakha (http://www.tarekrakha.com/#/research/).
'Thermal Autonomy' (TA) is defined here as the the percent of occupied time where a point of space meets or exceeds a given set of thermal comfort acceptability criteria through passive means only.
Precedents for Thermal Autonomy (TA) as a metric to evaluate the passive operation of a given space can be found in the work of Brendon Levitt.
Levitt, B.; Ubbelohde, M.; Loisos, G.; Brown, N. Thermal Autonomy as Metric and Design Process. Loisos + Ubbelohde, Alameda, California, California College of the Arts, San Francisco. 2013.
(http://www.coolshadow.com/research/Levitt_Thermal%20Autonomy%20as%20Metric%20and%20Design%20Process.pdf)

index.name: Visualise Honeybeegeneration cashflow
index.summary: Use this component to the calculate and visualise the financial value of Honeybee generation systems over 25 years
index.description:
Use this component to the calculate and visualise the financial value of Honeybee generation systems over 25 years. At present you can only create grid connected renewable energy systems without storage. For this reason you must specify both the grid electricity price and fed in tariff rate.
The financial value of the Honeybee generator systems is calculated by calculating how much energy is consumed by the facility and produced by the Honeybee generator systems for every hour of the year.
For every hour of the year if electricity is generated and the facility requires electricity, the facility will automatically consume the electricity generated. This will generate a revenue as the facility did not have to purchase electricity from the grid.
Any surplus electricity generated in any hour throughout the year will be fed back into the grid at the tariff rate, and generate a revenue.

index.name: Color Edge Weight
index.summary: Assign a weight value to graph edges based on the color averaged for an edge. Values will be normalized to the 0...1 interval

index.name: Custom Edge Weight
index.summary: Assign a custom weight to graph edges - Warning ! If you reference mesh edges, naked edges will not be considered. Values are normalized in the 0..1 interval

index.name: Custom Face Weight
index.summary: Assign a custom weight to graph nodes (mesh Faces). Values are normalized in the 0..1 interval

index.name: Face Angle Edge Weight
index.summary: Assign a weight value to graph edges based on the angle between the faces connected by an edge. Values will be normalized to the 0...1 interval

index.name: Face Midpoint Distance Edge Weight
index.summary: Assign a weight value to graph edges based on the distance between the midpoints of the faces the edge conects. Values will be normalized to the 0...1 interval

index.name: Face Size Node(mesh face) Weight
index.summary: Assign weight to graph nodes based on the area of the mesh faces. Largest faces will have the smallest values.

index.name: Agents Control Random
index.summary: Create a series of trees on the given graph that spread out based on the limits imposed and the behavior given as a chance pick between two characters Explore and Consume

index.name: Agents Programmed Behavior
index.summary: Create a series of trees on the given graph that spread out based on the limits imposed and a programed behavior that switches between two characters Explore and Consume

index.summary: Compute the a tree from the graph using a Depth first search based on edge weight

index.summary: Compute the minimum spanning tree for the mesh graph using a modified Kruskal's algorithm

index.name: MST Kruskal concavity
index.summary: Compute the minimum spanning tree for the mesh graph including convex, concave and flat region detection. This uses a modified Kruskal algorithm with weight limits

index.name: MST Kruskal Valence
index.summary: Compute the minimum spanning tree for the mesh graph using a modified Kruskal's algorithm with max valence preference

index.name: MST Prim
index.summary: Compute the minimum spanning tree for the mesh graph using Prim's algorithm

index.name: Multi Root MST concavity
index.summary: Constructs a set of trees based on the given graph
index.description: Constructs a set of trees based on the given graph. The trees start from the given mesh face index and spread outwards based on the weighted MST criteria and never consider weight outside the specified interval. This version considers edge weight and factors in the weight the concave/convex sequence of edges

index.name: Multi Root MST edge weight
index.summary: Constructs a set of trees based on the given graph
index.description: Constructs a set of trees based on the given graph. The trees start from the given mesh face index and spread outwards based on the weighted MST criteria and never consider weight outside the specified interval. This version considers edge weight

index.name: Multi Root MST node weight
index.summary: Constructs a set of trees based on the given graph
index.description: Constructs a set of trees based on the given graph. The trees start from the given mesh face index and spread outwards based on the weighted MST criteria and never consider weight outside the specified interval. This version considers the node weight

index.summary: Creates a finite element model from given entities (points, beams, supports, loads, cross sections, materials,... ).

index.summary: Lists the connected parts of the active line elements of a model.

index.summary: Creates beams with default properties from given connectivity diagram

index.name: Disassemble Element
index.summary: Decomposes beams and shells into their components.

index.summary: Decomposes a model into its components

index.name: Element Activation
index.summary: Activates the elements of a model according to the activation list. Uses soft kill approach for inactive elements.

index.name: Index to Beam
index.summary: Creates beams with default properties from given node indexes.

index.name: Line to Beam
index.summary: Geometry is assumed to be given in [m]
index.description: Geometry is assumed to be given in [m]. Creates beams with default properties from given lines. Lines that meet at a common point are thus connected with each other. Karamba assumes input to be in meters.

index.name: Make Element-Set
index.summary: Puts elements designated by their element identifier into a group.

index.name: Mesh to Shell
index.summary: Geometry is assumed to be given in [m]
index.description: Geometry is assumed to be given in [m]. Creates shells with default properties from given meshes. Mesh edges that meet at a common point are thus connected with each other. Karamba assumes input to be in meter.

index.name: Modify Element
index.summary: Modifies all types of elements or creates element modifiers that do this when the model is assembled.

index.name: Modify Model
index.summary: Modifies a finite element model according to given entities (points, beams, supports, loads, cross sections, materials,... ).

index.name: Orientate Elem
index.summary: Sets the local coordinate system of elements.

index.name: Point-Mass
index.summary: Attaches a point mass to a node of given index or position. Does not result in additional weight, only inertia!

index.name: Select Element
index.summary: Selects elements according to given criteria and puts all incoming beams in two groups: selected or rejected.

index.name: Support
index.summary: Creates supports at nodes of given node-indexes or node-coordinates. Lets you select translations/rotations which should be zero.

index.name: Disassemble Mesh Load
index.summary: Converts mesh-loads to point- and element-loads.

index.name: Loads
index.summary: Creates all types of loads for a structural model.

index.name: Prescribed Displacement
index.summary: Prescribes displacements at nodes of given node-indexes or node-coordinates
index.description: Prescribes displacements at nodes of given node-indexes or node-coordinates. Select translations/rotations which should be prescribed. For load-cases with no displacements prescribed this will create a support.

index.name: Beam-Joint-Agent
index.summary: Sets a hinge at the connection of a beam to another element or node.

index.name: Beam-Joints
index.summary: Add hinges at the end-points of beams.

index.name: Cross Section
index.summary: Creates all types of cross sections.

index.name: Cross Section Matcher
index.summary: Returns for a cross section the best fitting cross section contained in a given list. The matched cross section is equal or better in all mechanical aspects at minimum weight.

index.name: Cross Section Range Selector
index.summary: Lets you select cross sections by country, shape, family or maximum depth or width.

index.name: Cross Section Selector
index.summary: Lets you select cross sections by name or regular expression from a list of cross sections.

index.name: Disassemble Cross Section
index.summary: Retrieves properties of a cross section.

index.name: Eccentricity on Beam
index.summary: Sets the eccentricity of a cross section relative to the element axis in global coordinates.

index.name: Eccentricity on Cross Section
index.summary: Sets the eccentricity of a cross section relative to the element axis in local beam coordinates.

index.name: Generate Cross Section Table
index.summary:
Converts a list of cross sections into a string
which can be streamed as a csv-file and used as a cross section table
index.description:
Converts a list of cross sections into a string
which can be streamed as a csv-file and used as a cross section table. Use 'Save cross section table to file' from the context menu to save the table to '.bin', '.dat' or '.csv' files

index.name: Modify Cross Section
index.summary: Modifies all types of cross sections.

index.name: Read Cross Section Table from File
index.id: Read Cross Section Table from File
index.summary: Reads cross section data from a csv-file.

index.name: Disassemble Material
index.summary: Retrieves properties of a material.

index.name: Material Properties
index.summary: Sets the characteristic parameters of a material.

index.name: Material Selection
index.summary: Lets you select a materials by name or regular expression from a list of materials.

index.name: Read Material Table from File
index.summary: Reads a list of materials from a table given in csv-format.

index.name: Analyze
index.summary: Calculates the deflections of a given model using first order theory for small deflections.

index.name: Analyze Nonlinear WIP
index.summary: Calculates the nonlinear response of the model. Is work in progress (WIP)

index.name: AnalyzeThII
index.summary: Calculates the deflections of a given model using second order theory for small deflections.

index.name: BESO for Beams
index.summary: Bidirectional Evolutionary Structural Optimization for beam structures.

index.name: BESO for Shells
index.summary: Bidirectional Evolutionary Structural Optimization for shell structures.

index.name: Buckling Modes
index.summary: Calculates the buckling modes of the given model under a specified load case and the buckling load factors. Returns positive buckling load factors only.

index.name: Eigen Modes
index.summary: Calculates the eigen modes of the given model according to the special eigenvalue problem.

index.name: Large Deformation Analysis
index.summary: Does incremental geometrically non-linear analysis for loads in load case zero.

index.name: Natural Vibrations
index.summary: Calculates the natural vibrations of the given model.

index.name: Optimize Cross Section
index.summary: Selects optimum cross sections for beams and shells in the model according to EC3 (EN 1993-1-1) for steel structures. For beams the procedure of annex B is applied.

index.name: Optimize Reinforcement
index.summary: Selects optimum reinforcement for shells according to the approach proposed by Marti (see Marti, P
index.description: Selects optimum reinforcement for shells according to the approach proposed by Marti (see Marti, P., Dimensioning and detailing, in IABSE Colloquium Report, Vol 62, Stuttgart, Germany, 1991, pp. 411-443).

index.name: Tension/Compression Eliminator
index.summary: Removes elements under axial tension or compression. By default compression members will be removed.

index.name: Beam Displacements
index.summary: Returns displacements along beams: translations/rotations in global x-, y-, and z-direction; rotations about global x-, y- and z-axis.

index.name: Beam Forces
index.summary: Retrieves section forces for all beam elements of the model.

index.name: Beam Resultant Forces
index.summary: Retrieves maximum resultant section forces for all beam elements of the model.

index.name: Beam View
index.summary: Lets you set the display properties of beams and trusses. Plug it into the definition after a ModelView-component so that you can fine-tune the model display with it.

index.name: Deformation-Energy
index.summary: Retrieves deformation energies of the elements of the model.

index.name: Line Results on Shells
index.summary: Returns results as lines painted on the shell mesh. The considered loadcase is that set at the nearest upstream ModelView-component.

index.name: Model View
index.summary:
Lets you inspect the current state of the model.
Plug it into the data pipeline in front of 'Beam View' or 'Shell View' to control the overall model display.

index.name: Nodal Displacements
index.summary: Returns nodal displacements: translations/rotations in global x-, y-, and z-direction; rotations about global x-, y- and z-axis.

index.name: Principal Strains Approximation
index.summary: Approximates the principal strain directions from the model deformation at arbitrary points.

index.name: Reaction Forces
index.summary: Returns reaction forces and moments at supports.

index.name: Result Vectors on Shells
index.summary: Returns results as vectors. The considered loadcase is that set at the nearest upstream ModelView-component.

index.name: Shell Forces
index.summary: Retrieves section forces for all shell elements of the model.

index.name: Shell View
index.summary: Lets you inspect the current state of the shells in a model. Plug it into the definition after a ModelView-component so that you can fine-tune the model display with it.

index.name: Utilization of Elements
index.summary: Returns the utilization of beams or shells for each load case according to Eurocode 3
index.description: Returns the utilization of beams or shells for each load case according to Eurocode 3. For shells the ratio between Van Mises Stress and yield stress is returned and buckling is not considered. 1 means 100%. By default all elements are included.

index.name: Export Model to DStV

index.summary: Adds an additional LIN movement at the beginning and/or at the end of a list of robot movement commands. The LIN movement will be offset according to the cartesian XYZ values.

index.name: Orient Plane
index.summary: Orients the -X axis of a plane to a given point.

index.summary: Reduces a list of LINear movements, similar to 'Reduce Polyline' but also respecting the changing angle values. Only input LINear movements.

index.name: Safe Plane
index.summary: Adds an additional LIN movement at the beginning and/or at the end of a list of robot movement commands. The origin of the LINear movement will be projected onto a plane.

index.name: Tangential Offset
index.summary: Adds an additional LIN movement at the beginning and/or at the end of a list of robot movement commands. The LIN movement will be offset tangentially, e.g. to start a toolpath outside of the material.

index.name: Tool Axis Offset
index.summary: Adds an additional LIN movement at the beginning and/or at the end of a list of robot movement commands. The LIN movement will be offset along the tool axis, e.g. for approach movements.

index.name: 3 Points to Plane
index.summary: Turns a set of three points into a plane, to be used in a KUKA|prc movement command

index.name: Analog Output
index.summary: Changes the state of an analogue output.

index.name: Command Weaver
index.summary: This component will weave together KUKA|prc commands
index.description: This component will weave together KUKA|prc commands. You may require a certain sequence of events, e.g. move PTP, open gripper, move LIN down, close gripper, move LIN up... When using the Command Weaver, put in all move PTP commands in the first input, all open gripper commands in the second input etc. The command weaver will then take the first item from the first input, then the first item from the second input... weaving together the command structure. If you enable the tree option, weaving will take place according to tree branches, instead of individual items.
